awd_titl_txt: Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2019:  The Diversity of a New Carbon-Activating Halogenase from Cyanobacteria
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2019, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will utilize biological collections in innovative ways. Photosynthetic bacteria known as cyanobacteria produce a variety of organic molecules with unusual chemical structures, including halogenated molecules, which contain chlorine and bromine and are produced using enzymes called halogenases. The enzymes are unusual because they can form chemical bonds at carbon atoms that other enzymes cannot use. A better understanding of halogenases will lead to new insights in chemistry. Towards that goal, the fellow will study a newly discovered type of halogenase that is able to attach halogen atoms to molecules called fatty acids. This project will lay the groundwork for understanding a new type of carbon-activating enzyme, with applications for the development of new synthetic methods in chemistry to produce industrially important molecules. The fellow will engage in public outreach, including interactive museum exhibits, to highlight the importance of microbiology in every-day human life.

In an international collaboration with the University of Porto, Portugal, this research will use DNA sequence data to identify new halogenases from the LEGE collection of cyanobacteria. Using a PCR-based approach, the fellow will identify LEGE strains that contain homologs of a fatty acid halogenase, with follow-up validation by whole genome sequencing. The fellow will clone, heterologously express, purify, and functionally characterize the new homologs from the LEGE collection, in addition to homologs from other culture collections, to identify genetic determinants of enzyme selectivity and explore the relationships between evolution and enzyme activity. The fellow will also use liquid chromatography and mass spectrometry to identify new halogenated compounds produced by species in the LEGE collection. The fellow will isolate and structurally characterize these compounds with the goal of connecting new halogenase-containing biosynthetic gene clusters to the molecules they produce. By characterizing the functional and genetic diversity of fatty acid halogenases in cyanobacteria, this work will document the utility of new halogenases for carbon activation in chemical synthesis. In performing this research, the fellow will receive training in bioinformatics, chemical synthesis, and natural products isolation and characterization. This research will be performed with assistance from undergraduates, whom the fellow will train and mentor, and it will build new collaborations for the analysis of interdisciplinary datasets in chemistry and biology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on characterizing the diversity of an enzyme family that halogenates fatty acids. This enzyme family, whose first characterized member was the enzyme CylC, activates carbon-hydrogen bonds to create new carbon-chlorine or carbon-bromine bonds with selectivity that is difficult to achieve using synthetic chemistry. With a long-term goal of improving synthetic methods for carbon-hydrogen bond activation, this project aimed to use chemistry and biochemistry to better understand the substrate specificity and products of CylC homologs. It also aimed to discover new natural products that are created from CylC-containing biosynthetic pathways. As CylC homologs are found predominantly in cyanobacteria, this project made extensive use of the LEGE cyanobacteria collection in a collaborative effort with the University of Porto.

Two main strategies were employed to characterize new CylC homologs. First, heterologous expression and purification was used to isolate proteins of interest for direct biochemical analysis. This approach found mixed success. Most homologs were unable to be purified as soluble proteins; however, several sparingly soluble homologs were found that are promising leads for future work. Second, and more successfully, synthetic chemistry was used to create deuterated fatty acids for stable isotope feeding experiments. These chemical probes revealed the substrate preference and site-selectivity of new CylC homologs in their native hosts without the need for protein purification.

To discover new CylC-derived natural products, liquid chromatography and mass spectrometry was used to identify metabolites whose production requires chloride. This approach successfully identified a set of chlorinated molecules produced by the cyanobacterium Nostoc punctiforme ATC 29133. Isolation and chemical characterization revealed these molecules to be a family of unusual glycolipids that are produced by a CylC-containing biosynthetic pathway. As determined from the chemical structures and stable isotope feeding experiments, the Nostoc CylC homolog possesses a unique substrate preference and site-selectivity, revealing valuable information about the diversity of CylC homologs and their corresponding natural products.

Through the research aims, this interdisciplinary project supported valuable training experience in methods including bioinformatics, microbiology, genetics, synthetic chemistry, natural product isolation, nuclear magnetic resonance, and mass spectrometry. In addition, through weekly volunteer efforts at the Harvard Museum of Natural History, it supported interactive live microbiology demonstrations for hundreds of museum visitors to bring awareness to the role of microbes in our daily lives. Overall, the project was successful in terms of training, scientific results, and broader impacts.
